title: Cause of Accidental Release of Radiation

content.description: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster led to the release of massive radiation, specifically <math alttext="iodine 131" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>iodine-</mtext><mn>131</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="cesium 137" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cesium-</mtext><mn>137</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, which has been connected to a variety of environmental problems in the <math alttext="30" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> years following the disaster.
content.question: A meltdown in which of the following structures at a nuclear power plant, such as Chernobyl, would most likely lead to the accidental release of radiation?

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Explain environmental concepts, processes, or models in applied contexts.
